01-01.title: Emancipation Proclamation
01-01.description: President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, declaring all slaves in Confederate territory to be free. This pivotal moment in American history transformed the Civil War into a fight for freedom and changed the course of the nation.

01-01.title: Cuban Revolution
01-01.description: Fidel Castro's revolutionary forces successfully overthrew Cuban President Fulgencio Batista, marking the beginning of communist rule in Cuba. This event reshaped Caribbean politics and U.S.-Latin American relations for decades to come.

07-20.title: Apollo 11 Moon Landing
07-20.description: NASA's Apollo 11 mission successfully landed the first humans on the Moon. Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first people to walk on the lunar surface, with Armstrong's famous words 'That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind' marking one of humanity's greatest achievements.

12-17.title: First Powered Flight
12-17.description: Orville and Wilbur Wright achieved the first successful powered, controlled airplane flight in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. This 12-second flight covered 120 feet and revolutionized transportation, marking the birth of modern aviation.

12-27.title: HMS Beagle begins voyage
12-27.description: The HMS Beagle departed on its second survey voyage with Charles Darwin aboard as the ship's naturalist. This five-year journey would provide Darwin with the observations and specimens that would later form the basis of his revolutionary theory of evolution by natural selection.

12-27.title: IMF and World Bank established
12-27.description: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank were officially created following the Bretton Woods Conference. These institutions were designed to rebuild the international economic system and prevent another Great Depression, fundamentally shaping global economic governance for decades to come.

12-27.title: Apollo 8 returns to Earth
12-27.description: Apollo 8, the first manned spacecraft to orbit the Moon, successfully returned to Earth. The crew became the first humans to see the far side of the Moon and witness an Earthrise, capturing the iconic photograph that would inspire the environmental movement.

12-28.title: First commercial movie screening - Lumiﾃｨre Brothers
12-28.description: Auguste and Louis Lumiﾃｨre held the first commercial public screening of projected motion pictures at the Grand Cafﾃｩ in Paris. This event marked the birth of cinema as we know it today, revolutionizing entertainment and visual storytelling for generations to come.

12-28.title: Galileo observes Neptune
12-28.description: Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei made the first recorded observation of the planet Neptune, though he mistook it for a fixed star. It would be more than two centuries before Neptune was officially recognized as a planet by Johann Galle in 1846.

12-28.title: Endangered Species Act signed
12-28.description: President Richard Nixon signed the Endangered Species Act into law in the United States, providing for the conservation of species threatened with extinction. This landmark legislation has helped protect countless species and their habitats, fundamentally changing environmental policy.

12-29.title: Texas Admission Day
12-29.description: Texas was admitted to the United States as the 28th state. The annexation of Texas represented a major expansion of U.S. territory and marked the beginning of Texas's transformation into one of America's most dynamic and culturally diverse states.

12-29.title: Pablo Casals Born
12-29.description: Pablo Casals, one of the greatest cellists of all time, was born in Catalonia, Spain. His innovative techniques and passionate performances revolutionized cello playing and inspired generations of musicians. He was also a renowned conductor and humanitarian.

12-29.title: Irish Constitution Comes into Effect
12-29.description: The Constitution of Ireland came into force, establishing Ireland as a sovereign, independent democratic state. This marked a significant milestone in Irish history, replacing the Irish Free State constitution and affirming Ireland's autonomy and cultural identity.

04-15.title: RMS Titanic sinks
04-15.description: The RMS Titanic sank in the North Atlantic Ocean after striking an iceberg during her maiden voyage from Southampton to New York City. Of the estimated 2,224 passengers and crew aboard, more than 1,500 died, making it one of the deadliest peacetime maritime disasters in history.

11-09.title: Fall of the Berlin Wall
11-09.description: The Berlin Wall, which had divided East and West Berlin for 28 years, was opened. This momentous event symbolized the end of the Cold War and led to the reunification of Germany, fundamentally changing the political landscape of Europe.

08-06.title: Atomic bombing of Hiroshima
08-06.description: The United States dropped the first atomic bomb used in warfare on the Japanese city of Hiroshima. The bombing killed an estimated 80,000 people immediately and tens of thousands more from radiation effects, marking the beginning of the nuclear age.

08-15.title: End of World War II - Japan surrenders
08-15.description: Emperor Hirohito announced Japan's unconditional surrender in World War II via radio broadcast, marking the end of the war. This day is commemorated in Japan as the 'day of the end of the war' (邨よ姶險伜ｿｵ譌･) and represents a turning point in Japanese history.

03-11.title: Great East Japan Earthquake and Tsunami
03-11.description: A magnitude 9.0 earthquake struck off the coast of Tohoku, Japan, triggering a devastating tsunami that killed over 15,000 people. The disaster also caused the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accident, making it one of the most significant natural disasters in modern Japanese history.

10-23.title: Meiji Era begins in Japan
10-23.description: The Meiji Restoration marked the end of the Tokugawa shogunate and the restoration of imperial rule in Japan under Emperor Meiji. This period of rapid modernization and westernization transformed Japan into a major world power.

07-04.title: U.S. Declaration of Independence
07-04.description: The Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence, announcing the thirteen American colonies' separation from Great Britain. This founding document established the principles of individual liberty and self-governance that would shape American democracy.

10-29.title: Black Tuesday - Stock Market Crash
10-29.description: The Wall Street stock market crashed on 'Black Tuesday,' marking the beginning of the Great Depression. Over 16 million shares were traded in panic selling, wiping out thousands of investors and triggering a worldwide economic crisis that lasted a decade.

05-29.title: First ascent of Mount Everest
05-29.description: Edmund Hillary of New Zealand and Tenzing Norgay, a Sherpa of Nepal, became the first climbers confirmed to reach the summit of Mount Everest. Their achievement marked a milestone in mountaineering history and human determination to conquer Earth's highest peak.

06-06.title: D-Day - Normandy Landings
06-06.description: Allied forces launched Operation Overlord, the largest amphibious invasion in history, on the beaches of Normandy, France. This pivotal World War II operation marked the beginning of the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi occupation.

03-15.title: Assassination of Julius Caesar
03-15.description: Roman dictator Julius Caesar was assassinated by a group of senators led by Marcus Junius Brutus. This event marked a turning point in Roman history, ultimately leading to the end of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire.

09-11.title: September 11 attacks
09-11.description: A series of four coordinated terrorist attacks by the Islamic terrorist group al-Qaeda against the United States killed nearly 3,000 people. The attacks led to the War on Terror, fundamentally changing U.S. foreign policy and global security measures.

02-14.title: Alexander Graham Bell patents the telephone
02-14.description: Alexander Graham Bell received a patent for the telephone, one of the most transformative inventions in human history. This device revolutionized communication, shrinking distances and laying the groundwork for our modern interconnected world.

12-25.title: World Wide Web becomes publicly available
12-25.description: Tim Berners-Lee and his team at CERN made the World Wide Web available to the public, releasing the first web browser and server software. This marked the beginning of the internet revolution that would transform communication, commerce, and access to information globally.

12-30.title: Soviet Union Established
12-30.description: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) was formally established, uniting Russia and several other Soviet republics. This marked the creation of the world's first communist state, which would become a global superpower and shape world politics for the next seven decades.

12-30.title: Flint Sit-Down Strike Begins
12-30.description: Auto workers in Flint, Michigan began a sit-down strike at General Motors factories, which would last 44 days. This historic labor action led to the recognition of the United Auto Workers union and transformed American labor relations, establishing the right to collective bargaining.
